Document the structure of each data source, including tables, fields, and data types.
Identify potential conflicts or discrepancies between data sources.
Define the target unified data structure.
steps.verification: Create a summary document listing data sources, their structures, and noted conflicts.
steps.tips: Start with small or representative datasets to avoid feeling overwhelmed.
steps.learningObjective: Accurately identify and document data sources and their characteristics for mapping.
commonMistakes: Assuming all data sources have similar structures without verification
Ignoring metadata or hidden fields

steps.title: Define Mapping Rules
subSteps: Identify key fields to map across sources (e.g., customer ID, email address).
Define mapping rules for each field, specifying direct mappings or required transformations.
Create a mapping table or document detailing source-to-target field mappings.
Validate mapping rules with stakeholders to ensure alignment with business needs.
steps.verification: Draft a mapping table with all source and target fields, including transformation logic.
steps.tips: Use consistent naming conventions to simplify the mapping process.
steps.learningObjective: Develop clear and effective rules for mapping fields from multiple sources.
commonMistakes: Overcomplicating mapping rules without considering simplicity
Failing to document rules for traceability

steps.title: Apply Transformations
subSteps: Apply data cleansing transformations (e.g., removing extra spaces, converting text case).
Standardize data formats (e.g., converting dates to a uniform format like YYYY-MM-DD).
Handle missing or invalid data by imputing values or flagging issues.
Test transformations on a sample dataset to ensure accuracy before full application.
steps.verification: Check transformed data for consistency and accuracy against defined standards.
materials: Data transformation tools (e.g., Excel, Python libraries, SQL)
steps.tips: Test transformations incrementally on subsets to catch errors early.
steps.learningObjective: Execute data transformations to standardize formats and values effectively.
commonMistakes: Applying transformations without thorough testing
Losing data integrity during conversion processes

steps.title: Ensure Data Integrity and Resolve Conflicts
subSteps: Validate the integrated dataset for completeness, accuracy, and consistency.
Identify and resolve conflicts (e.g., duplicate records, conflicting values between sources).
Perform integrity checks, such as verifying foreign key constraints or business rules.
Document the conflict resolution process and final dataset state for future reference.
steps.verification: Final dataset passes all integrity checks with no unresolved conflicts.
steps.tips: Document all decisions made during conflict resolution to maintain audit trails.
steps.learningObjective: Validate and resolve issues to ensure a reliable and unified dataset.
commonMistakes: Ignoring edge cases or rare data scenarios
Not documenting resolutions, leading to repeat issues

atomicExpansion.practicalExample: Map and transform customer data from an e-commerce website and a CRM system to create a unified customer profile. For instance, standardize email addresses to lowercase, merge duplicate records based on customer ID, and convert date formats to a consistent YYYY-MM-DD format.
finalVerifications: All data sources have been correctly mapped to the target structure.
Transformations have been applied without introducing errors or data loss.
Conflicts, such as duplicates or inconsistent values, have been resolved.
The integrated dataset passes predefined integrity checks (e.g., no null key fields).
The output dataset is ready for analysis or further processing.
Documentation of the mapping and transformation process is complete.
assessmentCriteria: Accuracy of mapping rules in aligning source and target fields.
Effectiveness of transformations in standardizing data formats and values.
Completeness of data integrity checks and conflict resolution.
Efficiency of the process in terms of time and resource usage.
Clarity and thoroughness of documentation for all steps.
Ability to handle edge cases and unexpected data scenarios.
crossCurricularConnections: Mathematics: Concepts of data normalization and statistical methods for handling missing data.
Computer Science: Algorithms for data mapping and transformation, and database management principles.
Business: Understanding data needs in marketing and analytics for decision-making.
Statistics: Techniques for data validation and error detection.
Communication: Documenting processes and collaborating with stakeholders effectively.
atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: This skill is applied in data warehousing projects to integrate sales data from multiple retail branches, enabling unified analytics for inventory management and customer insights. It ensures that data from different systems (e.g., point-of-sale, online orders) is consistently formatted and reliable for reporting.

individualConcepts.name: Adequação para Análises de Marketing
individualConcepts.description: Preparar a base de dados para ser utilizada em análises específicas de marketing, como segmentação, previsão de demanda ou avaliação de campanhas, através de ajustes e validações.

specificSkills.name: Aplicar Transformações para Marketing
specificSkills.description: Realizar ajustes nos dados, como criação de variáveis derivadas, limpeza ou agregação, que são essenciais para técnicas analíticas de marketing, otimizando a base para insights estratégicos.

steps.title: Understand Marketing Analysis Objectives and Data Needs
subSteps: Identify key marketing questions to be answered from data analysis
Review available data sources and assess their relevance to marketing goals
Define the scope and types of data transformations required (e.g., cleaning, derivation, aggregation)
Consult with marketing stakeholders to align data requirements with business objectives
Document marketing analysis objectives and success criteria for data transformations
steps.verification: Completion of a documented list of marketing objectives and corresponding data needs
steps.materials: Marketing strategy documents, data catalogs, stakeholder meeting notes
steps.tips: Start with high-level business goals to ensure data transformations drive actionable insights
steps.learningObjective: Articulate the purpose and scope of data transformations in the context of specific marketing analyses
steps.commonMistakes: Skipping stakeholder consultation or failing to align transformations with strategic marketing goals

steps.title: Clean and Preprocess Data for Marketing Use
subSteps: Identify and handle missing, duplicate, or inconsistent data points
Detect and address outliers and errors that could skew marketing analysis
Standardize data formats (e.g., date formats, categorical values) for consistency
Ensure data privacy and compliance with regulations (e.g., GDPR for marketing data)
Validate cleaned data through basic statistical summaries and visual checks
steps.verification: Data cleaning report detailing before-and-after status and issues resolved
steps.materials: Data cleaning tools (e.g., Python with pandas, Excel), data dictionaries, privacy guidelines
steps.tips: Use automated scripts for repetitive cleaning tasks to improve efficiency and accuracy
steps.learningObjective: Prepare raw data to be reliable and suitable for marketing analytical techniques
steps.commonMistakes: Over-cleaning data, which might remove important variations, or ignoring privacy concerns

steps.title: Create Derived Variables for Enhanced Marketing Insights
subSteps: Define derived variables based on marketing needs (e.g., customer lifetime value, RFM scores)
Calculate variables using appropriate formulas and statistical methods
Test derived variables for validity, reliability, and correlation with marketing outcomes
Document variable definitions, calculations, and intended use in marketing analysis
Integrate derived variables into the main dataset without disrupting original data
steps.verification: Set of derived variables with complete documentation and validation results
steps.materials: Statistical software (e.g., R, Python), marketing metrics guides, calculation templates
steps.tips: Ensure derived variables are actionable, interpretable, and directly tied to marketing KPIs
steps.learningObjective: Enhance data with meaningful attributes that support deeper marketing insights and segmentation
steps.commonMistakes: Creating too many derived variables, leading to noise, or using irrelevant calculations

steps.title: Aggregate Data for Strategic Marketing Analysis
subSteps: Determine aggregation levels (e.g., by customer segment, time period, product category)
Perform aggregations to summarize data (e.g., total sales per region, average engagement per campaign)
Validate aggregated results for accuracy and consistency with raw data
Visualize aggregated data using charts or dashboards to identify trends and patterns
Align aggregations with marketing KPIs and strategic decision-making needs
steps.verification: Aggregated datasets and visualizations ready for analysis and stakeholder review
steps.materials: Aggregation tools (e.g., SQL, Excel PivotTables), visualization software (e.g., Tableau, Power BI)
steps.tips: Use aggregations to highlight key insights without losing necessary granularity for detailed analysis
steps.learningObjective: Summarize data effectively to support high-level strategic marketing decisions and reporting
steps.commonMistakes: Aggregating too much data, obscuring important details, or misaligning with marketing goals

steps.title: Validate and Optimize the Transformed Database
subSteps: Conduct final data quality checks on the entire transformed dataset
Compare transformed data against original marketing objectives and requirements
Optimize database structure and indexing for query performance in marketing tools
Document the entire transformation process, including steps, tools used, and decisions made
Obtain feedback from marketing end-users and iterate based on their input
steps.verification: Final validation report and approval from stakeholders confirming readiness for analysis
steps.materials: Validation scripts, performance monitoring tools, documentation templates, feedback forms
steps.tips: Iterate the transformation process based on user feedback to continuously improve data utility
steps.learningObjective: Ensure the transformed database is accurate, performant, and fully aligned with marketing analysis needs
steps.commonMistakes: Rushing validation, inadequate documentation, or not incorporating stakeholder feedback

atomicExpansion.practicalExample: For a digital marketing campaign, transform web analytics data by cleaning session logs, deriving metrics like bounce rate and conversion probability, and aggregating data by traffic source to optimize ad spend and targeting strategies.
finalVerifications: All data transformations are correctly applied and thoroughly documented
Transformed data passes comprehensive quality assurance and accuracy tests
Marketing team confirms that the data meets all analysis requirements and objectives
Database is optimized for efficient querying and integration with marketing analysis tools
Backups of both original and transformed data are securely maintained
assessmentCriteria: Completeness and accuracy of data cleaning and preprocessing steps
Relevance, correctness, and documentation of derived variables for marketing insights
Effectiveness of data aggregations in supporting strategic marketing decisions
Adherence to data privacy, ethical standards, and regulatory compliance
Quality and clarity of documentation throughout the transformation process
crossCurricularConnections: Data Science for statistical methods and machine learning applications in marketing
Business Intelligence for reporting, dashboard creation, and data visualization
Ethics and Law for understanding data privacy regulations in marketing contexts
Project Management for coordinating transformation tasks and stakeholder communication
atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: In e-commerce, applying these data transformations to customer purchase history enables segmentation based on behavior, personalization of marketing messages, optimization of inventory management, and data-driven budgeting for campaigns, leading to improved ROI and customer satisfaction.

specificSkills.name: Validar Qualidade dos Dados
specificSkills.description: Verificar a integridade, precisão e consistência dos dados após a integração e transformações, assegurando que estejam prontos e confiáveis para análises de marketing.

steps.title: Define Validation Criteria and Metrics
subSteps: Identify key data attributes relevant to marketing analyses, such as customer demographics or purchase history.
Define specific metrics for data integrity (e.g., completeness, uniqueness), accuracy (e.g., correctness against benchmarks), and consistency (e.g., format standardization).
Set acceptable quality thresholds for each metric, like 95% completeness or zero duplicates.
Document validation rules and procedures in a data quality plan.
Review criteria with marketing stakeholders to ensure alignment with business goals.
steps.verification: Completed documentation of validation criteria and metrics approved by stakeholders.
steps.materials: Data dictionary, business requirements document, quality standards guide, stakeholder input.
steps.tips: Involve domain experts early to make criteria practical and avoid unrealistic standards.
steps.learningObjective: To establish clear and measurable data quality standards for marketing data validation.
steps.commonMistakes: Setting thresholds too high without considering data limitations or neglecting business context in metrics.

steps.title: Perform Data Integrity Checks
subSteps: Verify that all required fields are populated without missing values using automated scripts or tools.
Check for duplicate records by comparing unique identifiers like email addresses or customer IDs.
Assess missing data patterns and decide on handling strategies, such as imputation or exclusion.
Ensure referential integrity in relational data by validating foreign key relationships.
Validate data formats and types, such as date formats or numerical ranges, against predefined rules.
steps.verification: No unresolved integrity issues detected, with documentation of any findings and corrective actions.
steps.materials: Data cleaning tools (e.g., Python pandas, Excel), data schema, validation scripts.
steps.tips: Use automated checks to handle large datasets efficiently and reduce manual errors.
steps.learningObjective: To identify and address data completeness, uniqueness, and structural issues.
steps.commonMistakes: Overlooking null values in critical fields or misidentifying duplicates due to inconsistent data entry.

steps.title: Assess Data Accuracy and Consistency
subSteps: Compare data against trusted sources, such as historical records or external databases, to verify correctness.
Validate logical relationships between data points, like ensuring total sales match sum of individual transactions.
Check for outliers or anomalies using statistical methods, such as z-scores or visual inspection in dashboards.
Ensure consistency in units, formats, and naming conventions across all data sources.
Perform random spot checks on sample data to validate accuracy through manual review.
steps.verification: Data accuracy and consistency meet defined standards, with anomalies documented and addressed.
steps.materials: Reference data, validation rules, statistical software (e.g., R, SPSS), data visualization tools.
steps.tips: Cross-reference with multiple sources to enhance reliability and catch subtle errors.
steps.learningObjective: To verify data correctness and uniformity, ensuring it is fit for analytical use.
steps.commonMistakes: Assuming data is accurate without verification or ignoring standardization issues that affect analysis.

steps.title: Document and Communicate Results
subSteps: Summarize validation outcomes, including metrics passed, issues found, and resolution status.
Create a quality report with visualizations, such as charts or tables, to highlight key findings.
Recommend specific actions for data improvement, like cleaning scripts or process changes, if quality gaps exist.
Communicate results to stakeholders through presentations or meetings, emphasizing data readiness.
Obtain formal approval that data is ready for marketing analyses and archive the validation report.
steps.verification: Report delivered, stakeholders acknowledge findings, and data is approved for use.
steps.materials: Reporting tools (e.g., PowerPoint, Tableau), communication plan, stakeholder list.
steps.tips: Use clear, concise language in reports and focus on actionable insights to facilitate decision-making.
steps.learningObjective: To effectively communicate data quality status and ensure stakeholder buy-in for analysis.
steps.commonMistakes: Providing overly detailed reports without summaries or failing to involve key stakeholders in the communication process.

atomicExpansion.practicalExample: After integrating customer data from a CRM and an e-commerce platform, validate that email addresses are correctly formatted, no duplicate customer records exist, and purchase amounts are consistent with tax calculations to ensure accurate targeting for a new email marketing campaign.
finalVerifications: All validation checks from steps 1-3 are completed with no critical issues unresolved.
Data integrity, accuracy, and consistency meet the predefined quality thresholds.
A comprehensive quality report is created and documented.
Stakeholders have reviewed and approved the data for marketing analyses.
Any data corrections have been applied and re-verified to ensure reliability.
assessmentCriteria: Percentage of data records passing all validation metrics (e.g., target 98% or higher).
Number and severity of data errors identified and resolved during validation.
Time taken to complete the validation process compared to estimates.
Accuracy and clarity of the validation report in reflecting data quality status.
Stakeholder feedback on data readiness and usefulness for marketing decisions.
crossCurricularConnections: Statistics: Applying statistical methods for outlier detection and data distribution analysis.
Computer Science: Using programming and algorithms for automated data validation and cleaning.
Business Management: Aligning data quality with marketing strategies and ROI objectives.
Communication: Developing reporting skills to convey technical findings to non-technical audiences.
atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: In digital marketing, validating data quality ensures that customer segmentation and ad targeting are based on accurate and consistent data, reducing wasted ad spend, improving campaign performance metrics like CTR and conversion rates, and enabling personalized marketing strategies that enhance customer engagement.

mainTopics.name: Análise e Visualização de Dados
mainTopics.description: Aborda a análise descritiva de dados, métodos de visualização, e técnicas de formação de agrupamentos como métodos hierárquicos e não hierárquicos.

atomicTopics.name: Análise Descritiva de Dados
atomicTopics.description: Técnicas para resumir e interpretar dados através de medidas estatísticas como média, mediana, desvio padrão e frequências, aplicadas no contexto de marketing analítico.

individualConcepts.name: Medidas de Tendência Central
individualConcepts.description: Conceitos e técnicas para identificar o ponto central ou típico de um conjunto de dados, essenciais para resumir informações em marketing analítico, como desempenho de vendas ou comportamento do consumidor.

specificSkills.name: Calcular e interpretar a média aritmética
specificSkills.description: Aplicar a fórmula da média para dados de marketing (ex: gasto médio por cliente) e interpretar resultados no contexto de tendências de mercado, considerando limitações como valores extremos.

steps.title: Compreender o conceito de média aritmética e sua fórmula
subSteps: Revisar a definição: soma de todos os valores dividida pelo número de valores
Memorizar a fórmula: Média = Σx / n, onde Σx é a soma dos valores e n é a quantidade de valores
Identificar exemplos simples de cálculo de média (ex: notas de alunos, temperaturas médias)
Praticar a aplicação da fórmula com dados numéricos simples
Discutir por que a média é uma medida de tendência central útil
steps.verification: Resolver corretamente 5 exercícios de cálculo de média com dados fornecidos
steps.materials: Caderno, calculadora, exemplos de conjuntos de dados simples
steps.tips: Use mnemônicos para lembrar a fórmula (ex: 'Soma tudo, divide pela contagem')
steps.learningObjective: Capacidade de explicar o conceito de média e aplicar a fórmula corretamente em cenários básicos
steps.commonMistakes: Esquecer de dividir pelo número total de valores, incluir valores não numéricos na soma, erro de arredondamento

steps.title: Calcular a média aritmética com dados de marketing reais
subSteps: Coletar um conjunto de dados de marketing (ex: gastos de 10 clientes em uma campanha: [50, 75, 120, 90, 60, 200, 85, 110, 95, 70] em reais)
Contar o número de valores: n = 10
Aplicar a fórmula: 955 / 10 = 95.5
Interpretar o resultado inicial: o gasto médio por cliente é R$ 95,50
steps.verification: Calcular a média corretamente a partir de um novo conjunto de dados de gastos de clientes fornecido
steps.materials: Conjunto de dados de exemplo, calculadora, planilha eletrônica (opcional)
steps.tips: Use uma planilha para automatizar o cálculo e verificar manualmente
steps.learningObjective: Capacidade de calcular a média com precisão usando dados reais de marketing
steps.commonMistakes: Erro na soma dos valores, contagem incorreta de dados, não considerar unidades monetárias

steps.title: Interpretar a média no contexto de tendências de mercado e identificar limitações
subSteps: Analisar o resultado R$ 95,50: isso indica que, em média, clientes gastam cerca de R$ 95,50
Considerar tendências: se a média for maior que em campanhas anteriores, pode indicar aumento no engajamento
Identificar valores extremos: no conjunto, R$ 200 é um outlier que pode distorcer a média
Discutir limitações: a média é sensível a outliers; em marketing, um gasto muito alto de um cliente pode inflar a média, dando uma impressão errada do comportamento típico
Sugerir o uso de outras medidas (ex: mediana) para complementar a análise se houver outliers

steps.materials: Resultado do cálculo anterior, notas sobre contexto de mercado, exemplos de outliers em dados de marketing
steps.tips: Compare a média com a mediana para verificar o impacto de outliers
steps.learningObjective: Capacidade de interpretar criticamente a média no contexto de marketing e reconhecer suas limitações
steps.commonMistakes: Ignorar outliers, superinterpretar a média como representativa de todos os clientes, não contextualizar os resultados no mercado

specificSkills.name: Identificar e aplicar a moda

steps.title: Compreender o Conceito de Moda
subSteps: Definir a moda como a categoria mais frequente em um conjunto de dados.
Diferenciar moda de média e mediana com exemplos simples.
Identificar exemplos de moda em contextos do dia a dia, como cores preferidas.
Explicar quando a moda pode ser múltipla ou não existir em dados.

Limpar e preparar os dados, removendo duplicatas, erros ou dados irrelevantes.
Validar a organização dos dados com um checklist de qualidade, verificando completude e consistência.

steps.title: Calcular a Moda em Dados Categóricos

Identificar a categoria com a maior frequência como a moda.

Extrair insights sobre tendências dominantes no mercado baseados na moda.
Tomar decisões baseadas em dados, como ajustar estratégias de produto, estoque ou promoções.
Comunicar os resultados de forma clara para stakeholders, usando visualizações como gráficos de barras.

specificSkills.name: Calcular e interpretar o desvio padrão

Organizar os dados em uma tabela com colunas para meses e valores de vendas

steps.title: Calcular o desvio padrão manualmente e com ferramentas digitais
subSteps: Calcular a média aritmética dos valores de vendas mensais
Encontrar as diferenças entre cada valor e a média, e elevar ao quadrado
Somar todos os quadrados das diferenças
Dividir a soma pelo número de observações (para população) ou n-1 (para amostra)
Extrair a raiz quadrada do resultado para obter o desvio padrão
Usar funções como STDEV.P ou STDEV.S no Excel, ou std() em Python, para verificar o cálculo

Explicar que um desvio padrão baixo sugere estabilidade e previsibilidade nas vendas

Comunicar os resultados de forma clara para stakeholders não técnicos

steps.tips: Compare o desvio padrão com métricas similares de concorrentes ou períodos anteriores para contexto adicional

specificSkills.name: Calcular e interpretar a variância
specificSkills.description: Determinar a variância em conjuntos de dados de marketing (ex: variância na receita por região) para entender a dispersão absoluta, base para outras métricas estatísticas.

steps.title: Entender o Conceito e Fórmula da Variância
subSteps: Definir o que é variância e sua importância em estatística descritiva
Explicar a fórmula da variância: σ² = Σ(x_i - μ)² / N para população e s² = Σ(x_i - x̄)² / (n-1) para amostra
Diferenciar entre variância populacional e amostral, com exemplos
Discutir como a variância mede a dispersão absoluta dos dados

Usar a fórmula errada (população vs. amostra) sem justificativa

steps.title: Coletar e Preparar Dados de Marketing para Análise
subSteps: Identificar fontes de dados relevantes, como relatórios de receita por região ou campanhas de vendas
Coletar os dados em um formato estruturado, como tabela CSV ou Excel
Limpar os dados removendo valores faltantes, outliers ou inconsistências
Organizar os dados em uma lista ou matriz para facilitar o cálculo

steps.verification: Listar os dados coletados e explicar como foram preparados, incluindo justificativas para limpeza

steps.learningObjective: Ser capaz de preparar dados de marketing para calcular a variância de forma precisa

Ignorar a normalização de dados se necessária para comparações

steps.title: Calcular a Variância Passo a Passo
subSteps: Calcular a média (média aritmética) dos dados coletados
Subtrair cada valor individual da média para obter os desvios
Elevar cada desvio ao quadrado para eliminar valores negativos
Somar todos os quadrados dos desvios
Dividir a soma pelo número de observações (n para população, n-1 para amostra)

Esquecer de ajustar o denominador para amostras
Não documentar os passos intermediários para revisão

Não considerar fatores externos que podem influenciar os dados
Confundir interpretação com outras medidas estatísticas

specificSkills.name: Aplicar amplitude e intervalo interquartil
specificSkills.description: Usar amplitude e IQR em dados de marketing (ex: faixa etária de clientes) para resumir variabilidade, especialmente útil em segmentação e análise de outliers.

steps.title: Compreender os Conceitos de Amplitude e Intervalo Interquartil
subSteps: Definir amplitude como a diferença entre o valor máximo e mínimo de um conjunto de dados
Definir intervalo interquartil (IQR) como a diferença entre o terceiro quartil (Q3) e o primeiro quartil (Q1)
Explicar como amplitude e IQR medem a variabilidade ou dispersão dos dados
Diferenciar amplitude e IQR em termos de sensibilidade a outliers
Relacionar amplitude e IQR com outras medidas de dispersão, como desvio padrão
steps.verification: Compreensão demonstrada através da explicação oral ou escrita dos conceitos com exemplos simples
steps.materials: Material de estudo sobre estatística descritiva, exemplos de dados numéricos
steps.tips: Use analogias como a faixa de temperatura para entender amplitude de forma intuitiva
steps.learningObjective: Entender a definição e propósito da amplitude e IQR na análise de dados
steps.commonMistakes: Confundir amplitude com média, não considerar o impacto de outliers na interpretação

steps.title: Calcular Amplitude e Intervalo Interquartil
subSteps: Coletar e ordenar um conjunto de dados numérico
Identificar os valores mínimo e máximo para calcular a amplitude
Determinar os quartis Q1 e Q3 após ordenar os dados
Calcular IQR como Q3 - Q1
Praticar cálculos com vários conjuntos de dados para consolidar o aprendizado

steps.commonMistakes: Erros na ordenação dos dados, cálculo incorreto de quartis, esquecer de subtrair valores corretamente

steps.title: Aplicar Amplitude e IQR em Dados de Marketing
subSteps: Selecionar dados de marketing relevantes, como faixa etária de clientes
Calcular amplitude e IQR para os dados selecionados
Interpretar a amplitude para entender a variabilidade total dos dados
Usar IQR para analisar a dispersão central e detectar potenciais outliers

steps.tips: Compare amplitude e IQR com a média para obter insights mais ricos sobre a distribuição dos dados
steps.learningObjective: Aplicar amplitude e IQR para resumir variabilidade em contextos específicos de marketing

steps.title: Interpretar Resultados para Segmentação e Análise de Outliers
subSteps: Analisar a amplitude para determinar se os dados são amplamente dispersos ou concentrados
Usar IQR para definir limites para outliers (ex: valores abaixo de Q1 - 1.5*IQR ou acima de Q3 + 1.5*IQR)
Identificar e documentar potenciais outliers nos dados de marketing
Discutir como outliers podem impactar decisões de segmentação e campanhas
Sugerir ações práticas baseadas na análise, como ajustar estratégias para faixas etárias específicas
steps.verification: Relatório ou apresentação que discuta segmentação e identificação de outliers com base nos cálculos

steps.tips: Considere o impacto prático de outliers; alguns podem indicar erros, outros novas oportunidades de mercado
steps.learningObjective: Interpretar amplitude e IQR para tomar decisões informadas em marketing, focando em segmentação e detecção de anomalias

Calcula corretamente amplitude e IQR a partir de conjuntos de dados fornecidos
Aplica amplitude e IQR a um conjunto de dados de marketing realista ou simulado
Interpreta os resultados no contexto de segmentação de mercado e detecção de outliers
Propõe ações de marketing baseadas na análise de variabilidade usando amplitude e IQR

Clareza e profundidade na interpretação dos resultados

individualConcepts.name: Análise de Frequências e Tabelas
individualConcepts.description: Métodos para organizar e resumir dados categóricos ou discretos através de frequências, fundamentais em marketing analítico para tabulação de pesquisas e entendimento de distribuições.

specificSkills.name: Construir tabelas de distribuição de frequências
specificSkills.description: Criar tabelas de frequências para dados de marketing (ex: frequência de compras por categoria) a partir de bases tabuladas, facilitando a visualização de padrões.

steps.title: Understand and Prepare the Data
subSteps: Review the dataset to identify variables and categories, such as product types or purchase events.
Clean the data by removing duplicates, correcting errors, and handling missing values.
Identify the categorical variable for frequency analysis, e.g., product categories like Electronics or Clothing.
Ensure the data is in a tabulated format, such as a spreadsheet with clear rows and columns.
Document the data source, context, and any assumptions for reference.
steps.verification: Verify that the data is clean, relevant, and accurately represents the marketing context for analysis.
steps.materials: Dataset in CSV or Excel format, spreadsheet software like Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets, data cleaning tools if needed.
steps.tips: Use descriptive names for categories and variables to make the analysis intuitive and aligned with marketing goals.
steps.learningObjective: To prepare and validate data effectively for building frequency distribution tables in marketing scenarios.
steps.commonMistakes: Overlooking data inconsistencies, misinterpreting categories, or not documenting data sources, leading to inaccurate tables.

steps.title: Construct the Frequency Table
subSteps: List all unique categories from the prepared data, e.g., all product categories found in the dataset.
Count the frequency of each category by tallying occurrences in the data.
Organize the categories and their frequencies in a table format, such as rows for categories and columns for counts.
Add column headers like 'Category', 'Frequency', and optionally 'Percentage' for clarity.
Calculate relative frequencies or percentages if required, ensuring they sum correctly to 100%.
steps.verification: Check that all categories are included, frequencies are accurately counted, and the table is structured correctly with no formatting errors.
steps.materials: Spreadsheet software with formula capabilities (e.g., Excel for COUNTIF functions), calculator for manual checks.
steps.tips: Use sorting functions to organize categories alphabetically or by descending frequency for easier pattern recognition.
steps.learningObjective: To create a clear, accurate, and well-formatted frequency distribution table from marketing data.
steps.commonMistakes: Missing categories during listing, incorrect frequency counts due to data errors, or improper table formatting that reduces readability.

steps.title: Verify and Analyze the Table
subSteps: Verify that the total frequency matches the total number of observations in the dataset to ensure completeness.
Check for any anomalies or outliers in the frequencies, such as unusually high or low counts that may indicate data issues.
Interpret the table to identify patterns, e.g., which category has the highest frequency or trends over time.
Prepare a summary or brief report based on the findings, linking insights to marketing objectives like customer behavior.
Optionally, create visualizations like bar charts from the table to enhance presentation and understanding.
steps.verification: Ensure the frequency table accurately represents the data, provides actionable insights, and is ready for use in decision-making.
steps.materials: Frequency table, analysis tools (e.g., software for charts), marketing objectives document for context.
steps.tips: Compare the table's insights with business goals to draw meaningful conclusions, such as targeting high-frequency categories in campaigns.
steps.learningObjective: To validate the frequency table and derive meaningful patterns and insights relevant to marketing strategies.
steps.commonMistakes: Not verifying total counts, misinterpreting patterns without considering context, or failing to connect findings to real-world marketing applications.

atomicExpansion.practicalExample: For a dataset of 150 online customer purchases with categories like Electronics, Clothing, Books, and Home Goods: First, clean the data to remove any duplicate entries. Then, count the frequencies: Electronics appears 50 times, Clothing 40 times, Books 35 times, and Home Goods 25 times. Construct a table with columns 'Category', 'Frequency', and 'Percentage'. For Electronics, frequency is 50, percentage is approximately 33.3%. This table shows Electronics is the most frequent purchase, helping inform inventory decisions and promotional focus.
finalVerifications: All relevant categories from the data are included in the table with no omissions.
Frequency counts are accurate and match the original dataset totals.
If percentages are calculated, they sum to 100% or are appropriately normalized.
The table is properly formatted with clear headers and organized layout for easy reading.
Insights derived from the table, such as dominant categories or trends, are logically sound.
Any data limitations or assumptions are documented alongside the table.
The table is ready for presentation or further analysis, such as visualization or reporting.
assessmentCriteria: Accuracy: Frequency counts and calculations are correct and error-free.
Completeness: All necessary categories and data points are included without exclusions.
Clarity: The table is well-organized, with intuitive formatting and clear labels.
Relevance: The analysis directly addresses the marketing context, such as purchase patterns.
Insightfulness: Ability to identify and interpret meaningful patterns from the table.
Documentation: Proper recording of data sources, steps, and assumptions.
Practical Application: Connection of findings to actionable marketing strategies or decisions.
crossCurricularConnections: Statistics: Frequency distributions are a core concept in descriptive statistics for data summarization.
Business Administration: Applying data analysis to understand market trends and consumer behavior.
Computer Science: Using software tools for data handling, table construction, and automation.
Mathematics: Involving arithmetic operations for counting and percentage calculations.
Communication: Enhancing skills in presenting data findings effectively through tables and reports.
atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: In marketing, building frequency distribution tables is essential for analyzing customer purchase behaviors, segmenting markets, and identifying high-demand products or services. For example, a retail company can use these tables to track the frequency of sales across different product categories, enabling data-driven decisions on inventory stocking, targeted promotions, and product development. This supports optimizing marketing efforts, improving customer satisfaction, and driving business growth through evidence-based strategies.

specificSkills.name: Calcular e interpretar frequências relativas e acumuladas

Definir categorias relevantes para análise (ex: faixas de renda)
Verificar a completude e precisão dos dados

steps.title: Calcular frequências relativas para análises comparativas

Calcular frequências relativas acumuladas
Identificar pontos de corte (ex: percentis) usando frequências acumuladas

steps.title: Interpretar frequências e aplicar insights em contextos de marketing
subSteps: Analisar frequências relativas para identificar segmentos de clientes predominantes
Usar frequências acumuladas para determinar limiares de mercado (ex: 80% dos clientes têm renda abaixo de X)

Traduzir insights em recomendações práticas (ex: focar campanhas em faixas de renda específicas)

Testar a robustez dos cálculos com diferentes subconjuntos de dados
Aplicar as frequências em uma simulação de decisão de marketing e avaliar os resultados

Capacidade de explicar os conceitos a colegas ou stakeholders

atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: Na prática, calcular frequências relativas ajuda a identificar o perfil demográfico predominante em uma base de clientes, permitindo otimizar campanhas publicitárias. Frequências acumuladas são usadas para definir metas de vendas, como atingir 80% do mercado-alvo com uma campanha específica, ou analisar tendências ao longo do tempo, como mudanças na distribuição de renda dos consumidores.

specificSkills.name: Analisar distribuições de frequência para segmentação
specificSkills.description: Interpretar distribuições de frequência no contexto de marketing analítico (ex: distribuição de preferências por produto) para identificar segmentos de mercado e insights estratégicos.

subSteps: Revisar a definição de distribuição de frequência em estatística
Identificar como os dados podem ser categorizados para análise de frequência (ex: nominal, ordinal)
Explorar exemplos de distribuições de frequência em marketing, como preferências por produto
Praticar a criação de tabelas de frequência simples com dados fictícios
Discutir a importância de interpretar frequências para identificar padrões de mercado
